definitions_glossary.planck_information_capacity: Maximum bits in region = A/(4ℓ_P²·ln2) where A is surface area
definitions_glossary.holographic_bound: I ≤ A/(4ℓ_P²·ln2) - tightest bound on information
definitions_glossary.bekenstein_bound: I ≤ 2πRE/(ℏc·ln2) - bound based on energy and size
definitions_glossary.nat: Natural unit of information; 1 nat = ln(e) ≈ 1.44 bits
definitions_glossary.bit: Binary unit of information; 1 bit = ln(2) nats

information_per_planck_area.equivalently: ~1 bit per 4 Planck areas = 1 bit per 10⁻⁶⁹ m²

examples.comparison: More than all computers on Earth combined (2024: ~10²³ bits)
Most information in Milky Way galaxy

examples.note: Would require ~10⁶¹ kg to fill with black hole - far exceeds observable universe mass

implications.description: Scales with surface area, not volume

implications.implication: Black holes are maximum entropy objects
implications.description: They saturate the holographic bound exactly
3D space might emerge from 2D holographic encoding

definition.@value: The maximum information that can be stored in a region of space, equal to approximately 1 bit per 4 Planck areas of the bounding surface

related.relationship: Information and entropy are related: I = S/(k_B·ln2)

learning_objectives: Calculate maximum information in a region given its surface area
Understand why information scales with area, not volume
Appreciate that black holes are maximum-information objects
Connect holographic principle to information theory
common_errors: Missing that 4 Planck areas (not 1) per bit
Confusing bits with nats (factor of ln2)
physics_insights: Human brain uses ~10⁻⁵⁴ of theoretical maximum
